data.title: Long and winding roads: Imperial funeral processions to the city of Rome under Augustus and Tiberius
data.sourcetitle: Processions and the Construction of Communities in Antiquity: History and Comparative Perspectives
data.abstract: When 19-year-old Marcellus passed away in Baiae in 23 BC, his body was brought back to Rome and Augustus’ Mausoleum. The event marked a novelty. From then on, the Imperial house transported their deceased male members back to Rome, a procedure not practiced during Republican times, except for Sulla. In this chapter, I will analyse the funerary processions that escorted the remains of Marcellus, Agrippa (Campania 12 BC), Drusus (Germania 9 BC), Lucius Caesar (Massilia 2 CE), Gaius Caesar (Lycia 4 CE), Augustus (Nola 14 CE) and Germanicus (Syria 19 CE) to Rome.
